awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Unique Fatigue Behavior of Magnesium Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Most structural components in engineering, particularly those bearing repetitive loading and operating at an elevated temperature, are metals. Magnesium alloys are some of the lightest metals and exhibit the very desirable high strength-to-weight and stiffness-to-weight performance ratios. Moreover, these metals are nontoxic, which also underline their potential for biomedical applications. However, one major obstacle preventing magnesium alloys from a wider use is the limited understanding of their fatigue behavior--material behavior under repeated mechanical loads, which is unique among structural metals due to its complexity. This award supports a fundamental study of the fatigue behavior of magnesium alloys through direct experimental observations. The research will provide basic knowledge of the mechanisms of deformation that lead to failure due to fatigue, and a database of experimental observations to develop and validate material models essential for the engineering design of magnesium-based parts. The effort will promote the engineering science of light-weight, high-efficiency alloys; and advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and secure the national defense through cost-efficient applications in the automotive, aerospace, healthcare, and defense industries.  The research will be integrated into an education program involving both graduate and undergraduate students to facilitate an understanding of sophisticated scientific concepts in magnesium research. For example, an educational video with interesting experimental visuals and 3D animations will be developed for undergraduate students and public; and self-directed and open-ended projects with relevance to magnesium alloys will be integrated into the existing capstone senior design classes.

The characteristic fatigue behavior of magnesium alloys is the result of the existence of twins, twinning-detwinning activities, and their interactions with slips and grain/twin boundaries.  The overall objective of this research is to understand how twins and twinning-detwinning activities, respectively, contribute to fatigue damage in magnesium alloys. To achieve this objective, three types of experiments will be designed and conducted: 1) fatigue with no involvement of twins and twinning, 2) fatigue with significant involvement of twinning-detwinning, and 3) fatigue with pre-designed twins without involving twinning-detwinning. These experiments will be realized using a magnesium alloy with a strong texture, and a proper design of the stress state and loading history with respect to the material orientation.  Ex-situ experiments together with in-situ experiments using companion specimens will be conducted to facilitate microscopic characterizations. Fatigue microcracking with the influence of twins, twin-twin boundaries, and interactions of twining and grain boundaries will be observed to elucidate the major micromechanisms governing the fatigue processes. The results from the research will form a base to develop mechanism-based fatigue damage models for magnesium alloys and provide information for the design of magnesium alloys with improved fatigue resistance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Award Number: CMMI- 1762312 

Project Title: Understanding the Unique Fatigue Behavior of Magnesium Alloys

 Overview: Magnesium alloys are the lightest metallic materials that could be widely applied in engineering structures and components due to the high strength and stiffness relative to their weight. The materials are recyclable and nontoxic that have potential bio-engineering applications. Structural components are unavoidably subjected to repeated or cyclic loading and fatigue failure is a major design concern. Due to the crystal structure, twinning, which is different from the much-studied dislocation slips, is an important mechanism accommodating plastic deformation in magnesium alloys. As a result, fatigue of magnesium alloys displays unique behavior characterized by three distinguishable regimes with each regime being associated with different involvement of twinning-detwinning activities. The NSF supported project was to enhance a fundamental understanding of the unique fatigue behavior of magnesium alloys. The research focused on the study of the influences of twins and twinning on the deformation and fatigue using a representative magnesium alloy through well-designed experiments and microscopic observations. The anisotropic mechanical properties of the magnesium alloy were investigated experimentally and comprehensively using different material orientations and under different combined stress states. Together with a microscopic characterization, the micromechanisms associated with the strength and ductility of the magnesium alloy were explored.

Intellectual merit: The NSF project allowed for a scientific exploration of the relationship between the microstructure and its evolution with the fatigue damage development during cyclic loading. A new deformation phenomenon related to the Swift effect was discovered for the first time in magnesium alloys. The study provides an understanding of the different fatigue behavior observed in the magnesium alloys from that of the conventional metals and alloys. The research bridges the macroscopic mechanical behavior and microscopic features for magnesium alloys, and it will help materials design and will enhance engineering applications of the lightest metallic structural materials. The results obtained from the NSF project provide a base for the development of mechanism-based fatigue models and cyclic plasticity deformation models to physically account for the microscopic changes during fatigue loading at both the macroscopic continuum and the crystal plasticity scales. The knowledge is critical to develop new magnesium alloys with improved fatigue resistance and to prevent the fatigue failure of magnesium alloys in engineering applications.

Broader impacts: In addition to the fundamental understanding of fatigue failure, the NSF supported project provides a database for engineering design and evaluation for the magnesium structures, which will promote the application of magnesium alloys and will benefit the U.S. economy and society.  The NSF project supported several graduate and undergraduate students who received training in the use of advanced material testing and measurement equipment. The results obtained from the NSF project form a major part of the Ph.D. dissertations of two graduate students. The concepts of twins, twinning, and detwinning are difficult to understand for most engineering students and engineers. An education video using three-dimensional computer atomistic animation together with direct in-situ experimental observations of twinning and detwinning obtained from the NSF project was created to facilitate the understanding of these concepts. The video and some of the results from the project will be used in undergraduate and graduate courses.


Last Modified: 06/28/2022
Modified by: Yanyao Jiang
